Title.evidence: Cost-Effectiveness of Primary Anastomosis versus Hartmann's Procedure for Perforated Diverticulitis: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to PA or HP in a 1:1 ratio after diagnostic laparoscopy.

Participants.evidence: Hinchey grade III or IV diverticulitis within the DIVA arm of the Ladies trial.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to PA or HP in a 1:1 ratio after diagnostic laparoscopy.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the cost-effectiveness of primary anastomosis (PA) compared to Hartmann's procedure (HP).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was 12-month stoma-free survival.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was managed centrally, and allocation was not concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 130 patients were randomised between July 2010 and June 2016, with 64 allocated to PA and 66 to HP.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted using a modified intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Mean costs per patient were lower for PA (€20,544, 95% CI 19,569 to 21,519) compared to HP (€28,670, 95% CI 26,636 to 30,704), with a mean difference of €–8,126 (95% CI –14,660 to –1,592).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered at trialregister.nl (NTR2037) and ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01317485).

Funding.evidence: Funding was provided by the Dutch National Health Care Institute.
